body.raw:
Welcome to the Badget documentation.

Badget is a community driven, open source personal finance tracker.
Think of it as the open source version to https://copilot.money

<Callout>

The documentation is still a work in progress. [We welcome contributions!](https://github.com/projectx-codehagen/Badget)\
You can follow updates on Twitter [@CodeHagen](https://twitter.com/CodeHagen).

</Callout>

body.raw:
1. Go to https://clerk.com and create an account

You will be redirected to the Sign In builder page.

2. Choose an application name and customize options if you want. Then, click **Create application**

You will be redirected to your dashboard. There is a section that says API Keys.

3. Copy these values to the appropriate location `.env.local` file.

body.raw:
1. Go to https://edgestore.dev/ and create an account

You will be redirected to your dashboard.

3. Click **Create your first project** and choose any project name

4. Copy the keys to your `.env.local` file

## Done!

All the setup required to use Badget is now complete!

Run `pnpm run dev` to start the development server and navigate to `http://localhost:3000` to see your app in action.

title: Setup
description: Just some basic web development prerequisites!

body.raw:
1. You need Node.js installed on your machine. You can download it from [here](https://nodejs.org/en/download/).
2. `pnpm` is our package manager. You can install it by running `npm install -g pnpm`

Confirm correct installation by running `node -v` and `pnpm -v` in your terminal. You should see the version numbers, if installed correctly.

3. Clone the repository by running `git clone https://github.com/projectx-codehagen/Badget`
4. Install the dependencies by running `pnpm install`
5. Run `cp .env.example .env.local`. You will store your environment variables in this file.

title: Planet Scale
description: Planet Scale is a hosted MySQL database

body.raw:
1. Go to https://planetscale.com and create an account

You will be redirected to the dashboard.

2. Click **Create a new database**

   1. Name your database whatever you want.
   2. Choose the region closest to you.
   3. Choose **Hobby** as the plan type.
   4. You will need to provide a credit card to continue. You won't be charged.
   5. Click **Create Database**.

You will be redirected to the integrations page. Select **Drizzle** and choose a password name.

Scroll down to the **Add credentials to .env** sectio and copy those values to your `.env.local` file. Set your database name as the `DATABASE_NAME` value.

Lastly, run `pnpm run db:push`

## Local Alternative

If you don't want to use PlanetScale, or don't have a credit card, you can use a local MySQL database. MySQL is open source and free to use.
[Here are instructions to get started](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql-getting-started/en/#mysql-getting-started-installing).

Enter `MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD`, `MYSQL_DATABASE`, `MYSQL_USER and MYSQL_PASSWORD` values in `.env.local`

Run `pnpm run db:push`

body.raw:
1. Go to https://resend.com/ and create an account

2. Choose any team name

You will be redirected to your dashboard.

3. Click **Add API Key** and copy the value to your `.env.local` file

4. In your `.env.local` file, set `TEST_EMAIL_ADDRESS` to the email address associated with your Resend account

body.raw:
1. Follow [these steps](https://docs.stripe.com/stripe-cli/) to install the Stripe CLI.

2. Go to https://stripe.com and click and create an account

Skip all prompts asking you to active your account. Navigate to https://dashboard.stripe.com/

3. Click on **API keys for developers**.

4. Reveal test key and copy the value starting with `sk_test_` to `STRIPE_API_KEY`

5. Click on the **webhooks** tab. Click on **Test in a local environment**. Find the `endpoint_secret` variable and copy that value to `STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET`

## Product key

1. Navigate to your terminal and run the following command using the Stripe CLI:

```bash
stripe products create  \
  --name=[enter any string name here. We are using "Pro Plan" and "Standard Plan"]
```

You will get this object back. Copy the `id` value to `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_STD_PRODUCT_ID`.

```json
{
    "id": [redacted],
    "object": "product",
    "active": true,
    "attributes": [],
    "created": ,
    "default_price": null,
    "description": null,
    "features": [],
    "images": [],
    "livemode": false,
    "metadata": {},
    "name": "Pro Plan",
    "package_dimensions": null,
    "shippable": null,
    "statement_descriptor": null,
    "tax_code": null,
    "type": "service",
    "unit_label": null,
    "updated": ,
    "url": null
},
```

Repeat the above step for another product with a different name. Copy the `id` value to `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PRO_PRODUCT_ID`.

## Price key

You will now create a price property for the two products you created.

1. Navigate to your terminal and run the following command using the Stripe CLI. You will need to run this once for each product you made with the respective name.

```bash
stripe prices create  \
  --currency=usd \
  --unit-amount=[any number you want, we are using 10 and 100 as examples] \
  -d "recurring[interval]"=month \
  -d "product_data[name]"=[the product name you chose in the previous step]
```

You will get this object back. Copy the `id` value to `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_STD_MONTHLY_PRICE_ID` and `NEXT_PUBLIC_STRIPE_PRO_MONTHLY_PRICE_ID` respectively.

```json
{
      "id": [redacted],
      "object": "price",
      "active": true,
      "billing_scheme": "per_unit",
      "created": ,
      "currency": "usd",
      "custom_unit_amount": null,
      "livemode": false,
      "lookup_key": null,
      "metadata": {},
      "nickname": null,
      "product": [redacted],
      "recurring": {
        "aggregate_usage": null,
        "interval": "month",
        "interval_count": 1,
```
